name: Plaça des Born
excerpt: Ciutadella’s main square is a gracious affair, framed by handsome 19th-century buildings like the neoclassical Palau Torre-Saura and fortress-like…
detail_description: Ciutadella’s main square is a gracious affair, framed by handsome 19th-century buildings like the neoclassical Palau Torre-Saura and fortress-like Ajuntament. The obelisk at its centre was raised to commemorate the townsfolk who died trying to ward off the Turks on 9 July 1558. For the finest view of the port and the town’s remaining bastions and bulwarks, sneak behind the ajuntament (town hall) and up to the 14th-century Bastió d’Es Governador.

name: Antiga Església del Roser
excerpt: This baroque early-18th-century church is now used as an occasional exhibition gallery.
detail_description: This baroque early-18th-century church is now used as an occasional exhibition gallery.

name: Carrer Ses Voltes
excerpt: The attractively arcaded central Carrer Ses Voltes is lined with smart shops, restaurants and bars.
detail_description: The attractively arcaded central Carrer Ses Voltes is lined with smart shops, restaurants and bars.

name: Ajuntament
excerpt: An imposing fortress-like building, Ciutadella's town hall dates from the 19th century.
detail_description:
An imposing fortress-like building, Ciutadella's town hall dates from the 19th century.
It now houses the tourist office.

name: Palau Torre-Saura
excerpt: The most grandiose of several 19th-century buildings overlooking Ciutadella's main square, with an impressive neoclassical facade. It's closed to the…
detail_description: The most grandiose of several 19th-century buildings overlooking Ciutadella's main square, with an impressive neoclassical facade. It's closed to the public.

name: Bastió des Governador
excerpt: This colossal bastion dates from the 14th century, but was heavily restored in the 17th century following the 1558 Turkish attack on Ciutadella. Clamber…
detail_description: This colossal bastion dates from the 14th century, but was heavily restored in the 17th century following the 1558 Turkish attack on Ciutadella. Clamber up for expansive views across the city's port.

name: Mercat de Peix
excerpt: Set in a pleasing 1895 building dressed in elegant green-and-white-check tiles, the city's small fish market is one of Spain's few remaining examples of…
detail_description: Set in a pleasing 1895 building dressed in elegant green-and-white-check tiles, the city's small fish market is one of Spain's few remaining examples of 19th-century cast-iron architecture.

name: Obelisco des Born
excerpt: Looming at the centre of Ciutadella's majestic main square, this obelisk monument honours the townsfolk who died trying to ward off the Turks on 9 July…
detail_description: Looming at the centre of Ciutadella's majestic main square, this obelisk monument honours the townsfolk who died trying to ward off the Turks on 9 July 1558, an attack which saw most of the city's buildings destroyed.

name: Naveta des Tudons
excerpt: Six kilometres east of Ciutadella, Menorca's best-preserved stone burial chamber was constructed around 1000 BC. The remains of over 100 individuals were…
detail_description: Six kilometres east of Ciutadella, Menorca's best-preserved stone burial chamber was constructed around 1000 BC. The remains of over 100 individuals were excavated here in the 1960s, most dating from the 9th century BC.

name: Castell de Sant Nicolau
excerpt: About 1km southwest of the town centre, this stout little 17th-century watchtower stands guard at the southern head of Ciutadella's port entrance. Views…
detail_description: About 1km southwest of the town centre, this stout little 17th-century watchtower stands guard at the southern head of Ciutadella's port entrance. Views over the waters to Mallorca and southwards along the coast are stunning.

name: Museu Municipal
excerpt: Within the 17th-century Bastió de Sa Font, the single, vaulted gallery of Ciutadella's town museum provides an excellent insight into the island's history…
detail_description: Within the 17th-century Bastió de Sa Font, the single, vaulted gallery of Ciutadella's town museum provides an excellent insight into the island's history through a small but eye-opening display of Talayotic, Roman and Islamic finds from the area. Comprehensive explanatory documentation is available in Catalan, Spanish, English and several other languages.

name: Catedral de Menorca
excerpt: Ciutadella's 14th-century, single-nave cathedral was built in Catalan Gothic style on the site of Medina Minurqa’s central mosque (the belltower visibly…
detail_description:
Ciutadella's 14th-century, single-nave cathedral was built in Catalan Gothic style on the site of Medina Minurqa’s central mosque (the belltower visibly reuses part of the original minaret), though its baroque facade with Corinthian columns wasn't added until the early 19th century. The cathedral was badly damaged during both the 1558 Turkish attack and the Spanish Civil War, leading to extensive 20th-century restorations.
Outside high season, it opens during hours of worship.

name: Església i Claustre del Socors
excerpt: The baroque Església dels Socors, with its lovely tile-patterned floors, was built between 1616 and 1670, and contains striking works by Menorcan artist…
detail_description: The baroque Església dels Socors, with its lovely tile-patterned floors, was built between 1616 and 1670, and contains striking works by Menorcan artist José R Torrent. Attached is the 18th-century Convent de Sant Agustí, home to a graceful whitewashed baroque cloister whose ceilings are carved with the emblems of major local families. Rooms branching off the cloister exhibit artwork and archaeological finds from across the island, while the convent's upper floors can be explored by guided tour only (€10, noon daily).

name: Palau Salort
excerpt: A couple of Ciutadella's magnificent noble homes are open to the public seasonally, including the splendid 1813 Palau Salort, which unfolds behind a…
detail_description:
A couple of Ciutadella's magnificent noble homes are open to the public seasonally, including the splendid 1813 Palau Salort, which unfolds behind a neoclassical facade. On the ceiling of the entrance hall you'll spot the Salort family crest, before climbing to the dance hall, British-inspired library, kitchen (allegedly Menorca's largest) and glimmering 'Room of Mirrors', whose walls are adorned with 12 Louis XVI mirrors.
In the evenings, the lobby morphs into a popular, atmospheric tapas and gin bar, Moriarty.
